High Availability

High Availability (HA) redundancy is provided for the PW EMS through the Kubernetes virtual platform on which it runs.

The Kubernetes virtual environment can be installed on a single server or multiple servers. HA synchronizes information, device configuration, system security, alarm and event notification settings, and system backup and upgrade settings in case of a failover scenario.

The PW EMS application is installed in a virtual environment that consists of one or more Kubernetes master nodes and one or more worker nodes, which contain pods.

  • A master is a collection of three server processes: apiserver, control manager and kube scheduler that run on a single node in a cluster which is designated as the master. The master controls each worker node.
  • A worker node is a worker system in Kubernetes. This node type has the container runtime services, kubelet and kube- proxy services, which are necessary to run one or more pods and is managed by master components.
  • A pod runs as a process on a node that can be part of a cluster that can be scaled up or down. A pod is the smallest deployable object in Kubernetes that can have one or more containers. The PW EMS instance runs in a pod container.

A user can be logged into a "replica" pod that contains an instance of the PW EMS UI. If this pod crashes for some reason, the PW EMS UI users are automatically logged out of this pod and need to log in again. Users that are logged into other replica pods that each have a PW EMS instance are unaffected. Multiple replica pods can exist on the same node or multiple nodes can contain an PW EMS instance that can be used in the customer deployment of the PW EMS application. These different deployments can help distribute HTTP requests across the different pods. There are multiple ways in which the Kubernetes virtual environment can be deployed for HA.

Refer to the Hardware Specification and Installation Guides for more information about how the PW EMS can be deployed for HA.

The following failure scenarios are supported by PW EMS HA functionality:
  • Server Failure Scenarios
    • Power failure.
    • Single server deployment failure causes the failure of the master node and one or more worker nodes.
  • Master Virtual Machine Failure Scenarios
    • Virtual IP connectivity failure.
    • Control Plane problems such as the unexpected termination of the database operations upon catastrophic failure, such as disk space limitations, bugs, and so on.
  • Worker Node Failure Scenario
    • The existing TCP connection between specific nodes results in a disconnect.
